New Records: Cleveland's five-run blitz in the first inning tied the MLB record for runs scored to start a postseason game before recording an out.
Key Match Events: Steven Kwan drilled opener Tyler Holton’s second pitch off the right-field wall for a leadoff double.
José Ramírez chopped a hard ground ball that third baseman Zack McKinstry couldn’t handle, allowing Kwan to score the game’s first run.
Josh Naylor followed with a single through the right side to score Fry.
Lane Thomas hit a three-run homer off Reese Olson.
Tanner Bibee used his recently reintroduced sinker to induce weak contact and prevent Detroit from building any semblance of a rally.
Cade Smith struck out Kerry Carpenter on three pitches and added three more punchouts in his postseason debut.
David Fry added two more runs with a double in the bottom of the sixth.
Pre-Game Insights: Lane Thomas expressed excitement to play in front of the Cleveland fans, saying 'I've heard this is a great place to play in the postseason.'
Post-Match Reflections: Lane Thomas described the Cleveland crowd as 'electric' and said it was everything he had thought and more.
AJ Hinch explained his decision to go to Reese Olson, stating 'We told him early in the day that the Lane Thomas at-bat was going to be it.'
Stephen Vogt praised his team's preparation during the five-day layoff, saying 'We worked them hard. To the players' credit, they put a ton of effort into our workouts.'
Miscellaneous Highlights: The game was played in front of a packed home crowd of 33,548.
Tanner Bibee threw 13 sinkers in Game 1, a pitch he recently reintroduced.
Cade Smith, the fWAR leader among all relievers in the regular season, has a strong case in the AL Rookie of the Year race.
